entry.title: Re: View's field is empty although it isn't empty in its...
entry.content:
If your Z-table is meant to store language-dependent texts (like descriptions), and SPRAS is part of the key, SAP expects a text table relationship. If this isn‚Äôt defined properly, the maintenance view might not display the language field correctly. To fix this, go to SE11 ‚Üí your Z-table ‚Üí Extras ‚Üí Language-Dependent Texts. Define the text table relationship properly. Ensure SPRAS is marked as a key field in the text table

If your maintenance view is joining multiple tables (e.g., a base table and a text table), and SPRAS is part of the key, the join condition must explicitly include SPRAS. To fix this, check in SE11 ‚Üí maintenance view ‚Üí check the Join Conditions. Make sure SPRAS is included in the join between base and text table. Without this, the system might not be able to match the correct language entry.

If the Z-table is not set up correctly as a text table, SAP might not treat SPRAS as a language key in views. To fix this, go to SE11 ‚Üí Z-table ‚Üí check Delivery Class. For text tables, use A (Application Table) or L (Text Table). Also check Table Category; it should be Transparent Table

entry.title: Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release
entry.content:
Keeping business users informed about system and company news is essential for organizational success. When users are aware of changes that could impact their daily tasks, they can make better decisions, adapt more quickly, and boost overall productivity. Staying up to date‚Äîespecially with updates on processes, departments, or system changes‚Äîhelps eliminate confusion and ensures alignment across teams.  

While our existing news feed provides valuable updates on SAP system changes, we‚Äôve listened closely to customer feedback and enhanced communication and user experience on My Home even further. In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, we now offer the ability to customize and manage the My Home news feed through the new Manage News application.

Manage News Application

 

Introducing the Manage News Application 

The Manage News application empowers news administrators to deliver timely, targeted information updates directly to business users via a centralized news feed. 

Key capabilities for news administrators include: 

  • Create, manage, and publish news articles: Administrators can compose news posts to be displayed on My Home, controlling the flow of critical company and system updates. 
  • Control visibility and importance: News items can be marked as critical, ensuring essential information is highlighted and receives appropriate attention from business users. 
  • Plan and schedule communications: Administrators can organize when specific news should be published, enabling timely and organized delivery of updates. 
  • Language adaptation: Messages can be tailored in all company-supported languages, ensuring effective communication across diverse user groups. 
  • Targeted audience assignment: News can be assigned to specific App Transaction codes, so only users with access to the corresponding Fiori apps or transaction codes will see relevant news items. 
  • Organize news by groups or categories: News articles can be grouped into categories such as Finance or Human Resources, making it easy for users to find pertinent information. 
  • Visual enhancements: Administrators can upload images aligned with news topics to make posts more engaging and visually informative. 

News article creation in Manage News Application

 

What Business Users Will Experience 

The My Home news feed now displays articles created by news administrators, neatly organized into designated categories. Critical updates are clearly marked with an eye-catching critical marker to ensure users notice and prioritize these messages. 

This personalized news feature centralizes essential communications in one place, tailored to the needs of each user based on their system app access. By delivering relevant, timely information directly to business users, organizations can foster a more informed and agile workforce. 

 Critical News displayed in My Home News Feed 

Critical News Article in My Home News dialog

 

Benefits for Your Organization 

With the Manage News application, administrators can tailor the news feed to reflect the specific needs of your company or organization, enabling more effective communication with business users. This streamlined and targeted approach to information sharing helps: 

  • Improve user awareness and decision-making 
  • Minimize confusion and misalignment across teams 
  • Increase adaptability to system or process changes 
  • Enhance overall company performance 

 

Prerequisites 

To access the Manage News application users or administrators will have to be assigned to the SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_MNG_PC business catalogue. For business users to view the news feed on My Home they will have to be assigned SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC catalogue. The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE role will already have SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC business catalogue assigned. With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, news maintained in the Manage News application will be displayed by default for all customers who have not configured a RSS feed or SAP Custom System News. To display the news from the Manage News application the 'Manage News App' setting needs to be enabled via UI Adaptation mode (Adapt UI in the User Actions menu). Users or administrator must have the catalog SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_FLEX attached to their role to access the UI Adaptation key user capabilities. 

My Home UI Adaptation Mode News Feed Settings

 

We‚Äôre excited to bring this powerful new communication feature to you with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release and look forward to seeing how it helps your business stay connected and informed. 

If you are interested in hearing about the latest innovations in SAP Cloud ERP, please join our Public Cloud Practitioner Forum in which SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers share best practices and provide feedback to the SAP development teams about new functionality. 

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/public-cloud-means-continuous-innovation-and-continuous-learning-new-user/ba-p/14017362 

(Open to SAP Cloud ERP customers, including partners running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.) 

Caroline Welsh, and Suneet Agarwal  on behalf of the SAP UX Foundations responsible for My Home in SAP S/4HANA.

entry.title: Re: Which development installation should I choose?
entry.content:
Hi!

Choosing the right development installation depends a lot on your project requirements, your development environment, and your goals. Here are a few things to consider:

  1. Project Type: Are you working on web development, mobile apps, backend services, or something else? Different installations and tools cater better to specific types of projects.

  2. Platform Compatibility: Make sure the installation supports your operating system (Windows, macOS, Linux) and any frameworks or languages you plan to use.

  3. Features and Tools: Some installations come bundled with extra tools like debuggers, emulators, or integrated package managers. Think about what features you need.

  4. Resource Usage: Lightweight installations might be better if you‚Äôre on limited hardware, while full IDEs offer more comprehensive features.

  5. Community and Support: Consider popular and well-supported options, as they tend to have more tutorials, plugins, and troubleshooting help available.

If you share more about your development goals and environment, the community can provide more tailored recommendations!

entry.title: Currency and unit conversion in SAP Datasphere Analytic Model with variable and value help
entry.content:
Currency conversion is the act of changing financial information from one currency into another. This process is especially crucial for global businesses that conduct operations across various countries and handle transactions in multiple currencies.

Unit conversion is also important because it ensures consistency, accuracy, and clarity when working with different measurement systems. Unit conversion enables accurate, effective communication and operations across systems, industries, and borders.

The following steps are carried out for currency / unit conversion in SAP Datasphere:

1. Create currency / unit conversion tables and views

2. Create a task chain and schedule it

3. Determine the semantic type and the associated unit in the fact view

4. Create input parameters with input help

5. Add conversion measure in analytical model

For currency conversion these tables must be available in your SAP S/4 HANA system:

  • TCURV - Exchange rate types
  • TCURW - Exchange rate type text
  • TCURX - Decimal places in currencies
  • TCURN - Quotations
  • TCURR - Exchange rates
  • TCURF - Conversion factors
  • TCURC - Currency codes
  • TCURT - Currency text

For unit conversion these tables must be available in your SAP S/4 HANA system:

  • T006 - Units of Measurement
  • T006D - Dimensions
  • T006A - Assign Internal to Language-Dependent Unit

    1. Create currency / unit conversion tables and views

a) Start the creation of the corresponding tables and views in the correct space in the Data Builder via Create and Currency / Unit Conversion Views

b) Choose source system and check objects. 

c) After clicking on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù, all objects are created automatically.

2. Create a task chain and schedule it

Create a task chain and include all relevant data flows to upload data into the required tables. To keep the data up to date, it is advisable to schedule the task chain.

3. Determine the semantic type and the associated unit in the fact view

In the fact view, which is located under the analytical model, you must maintain the semantic types of the key figures and the associated units. Conversion in the analytical model can only take place through this step.

4. Create input parameters with input help

If the user is to be provided with a value aid when calling up variables, one or more input parameters must be created in the fact view.

If you only want to provide users with a narrow list with a few units, you can build a view on the unit table and enter it here as value help. You can also set a default value here.

Attention: You may have to set the field length of WAERS to 3 in the view.

5. Add conversion measure in analytical model

a) You can now create conversion measures in the analytical model.

b) Enter business name and technical name for your new measure. Select source measure. SAP Datasphere uses the source key figure to recognize whether a unit or currency conversion needs to be carried out.

c) Select the date to which you want to convert and the appropriate exchange rate type (only for currency translation). Then click on the selection help for Target Currency and select ‚ÄúVariable‚Äù.

Click on "Use existing Source Variable" and choose the correct one.

d) Under ‚ÄúAdvanced‚Äù, select the client that is maintained in the TCURR table and what should happen if an error occurs.

TCURR:

e) Go back to main Analytic Model Properties and check error messages or test the new measure in preview.

Tip:

If the analytical model existed before the input parameters were created in the fact view below, they must be mapped manually to new or existing variables.

 

Conclusion

Currency and unit conversions are foundational components in ensuring data integrity, consistency, and meaningful analysis in multinational environments. SAP Datasphere offers a structured and streamlined approach to managing these conversions by leveraging integrated tables from SAP S/4HANA and guided steps within the Data Builder and analytical model.

By systematically creating conversion views, automating data flows through task chains, assigning semantic types, configuring input parameters, and defining conversion measures, users can implement robust, scalable conversion logic. This ensures that financial and operational data across diverse units and currencies are harmonized and ready for accurate reporting and decision-making.

entry.title: cTMS Setup for SAP Build Work Zone
entry.content:
cTMS Architecture ‚Äì SAP Build Work Zone

Here we have four environments Dev, QA, UAT, and Prod, each corresponding to a separate BTP subaccount. We have provisioned the Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS) in a separate subaccount. The development team develops their content and export the same from the Dev subaccount using Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS), which then adds the transport to the QA node. From there, it is imported into QA and the subsequent environments (UAT, Prod) through Solution Manager (SolMan), leveraging Focused Build (FB) or Charm status transitions.

Additionally, this setup can be integrated with SAP Cloud ALM

Setup Steps:

Since several of these SaaS applications share common setup steps, please begin by following the initial setup steps outlined here Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Step1: Create Service Instance for SAP Build Work Zone

We need to subscribe to SAP Build work zone, standard edition, with Application Plan, which you might have already subscribed when you are setting up SAP Build Work Zone. 

Here are the plans available, for cTMS setup, we need a service instance and key as well for setting up destinations to target subaccount for moving the transports. 

For creating Service Instance/key, you should already setup a space in your Cloud Foundry, if you did not setup yet. 

Navigate to corresponding space and create the Service Instance, chose the SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition and chose the standard plan, then create the Service Key. 

Note: you need to do this in all subaccounts including Dev. 

 

Step2: Create Destination to cTMS

We need to setup a destination with name "ctms_destination" in source subaccount, this is required for integrating with cTMS.

Name: should be "ctms_destination"

URL: uri found in the cTMS service key

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Token Service URL: uaa ‚Üí url from the cTMS service key 

Please use Client ID & Secret from cTMS Service Key. 

Step3: Create Destinations to CF Subaccounts

In the subaccount where the Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) service is subscribed, create a destination to each target SAP Build Work Zone subaccount. 

Name: Give appropriate name to resemble your CTMS Node

URL:https://portal-service.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/cdm_import_service

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Token Service URL: https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com

Please use the client id, secret, from the SAP Build Work Zone service key created in step1 above. 

Step4: Configure Transport Nodes in cTMS

Prerequisites

  • You have been assigned one of the following roles: Administrator or LandscapeOperator.

From the cTMS UI, you can define transport nodes to represent your system landscape. There are multiple ways to create a node:

You can either Create a node on the Landscape Visualization screen or from Transport Nodes screen. 

Allow Upload to Node: Enable this checkbox to allow file uploads to the node. Enabled for the Dev node only. 

Forward Mode: Default value is Auto, You can change this setting based on your landscape and transport flow requirements.

Controlled by SAP Solution Manager: Select this checkbox only if you plan to integrate with SAP Solution Manager (e.g., Charm or Focused Build). We will only enable this for QA and upper environments.  When you enable this, it will not allow manual imports from cTMS UI, only through Charm/FB status change. 

Note: If you plan to integrate with Cloud ALM, do not check this option. 

Content Type: For SAP BWZ, select Application Content.

Destination: Select the appropriate target destination you previously configured in your cTMS subaccount in Step3.

Step5: Create Transport routes in cTMS

In SAP Cloud Transport Management, transport routes are used to connect transport nodes.

Name: Provide the appropriate name

Chose the Source node & Target node and click on OK. 

After setting up Transport Nodes and routes, your landscape looks something like this based on the number of environments you have. 

Note: You can also use Transport Landscape Wizard, with which you can setup the all your landscape nodes & routes at a time.

Step6: Integrate with Solution Manager

To integrate Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) with SAP Solution Manager (Charm / Focused Build), follow the step6 from below article. 

If you want to integrate with Cloud ALM, follow the step7 from below article. 

 Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Conclusion:

I hope you learned, how to setup cTMS for SAP Build Work Zone. Now the setup is complete and ready for transporting the content using cTMS either integrated with SAP Solution Manager or Cloud ALM.

Thank you for reading  my article, feel free to provide any feedback or comment for any questions.

Thanks,
Raghu

entry.title: Vendor Returns & Subsequent Delivery Process in Purchasing
entry.content:
Vendor Returns & Subsequent Delivery Process in Purchasing

 

Return of goods helps us to return damaged or unwanted goods to the Vendor. A subsequent delivery is an additional delivery of Goods to meet the demand or fulfill the previous defective delivery.

There are situations when an order cannot be fulfilled with just one delivery due to lack of available stock.

Prerequisites ‚Äì

Creation of Material Master.

 

Creation of Suppliers.

 

Case 1:  Return to vendor when Purchase Order Available.

Purchase Order to be created.

Goods Receipt:

We would perform GRN of the PO Quantity with Movement Type 101.

Purchase Order History gets updated in the Purchase Order:

 

 

After GRN we find that 200 Kgs are defective and cannot be used so we have to return 200Kgs to the Supplier.

TCode: MIGO with Return Delivery with the previously posted GRN Material Document number (5000000041 in our case)

 

Movement type 122 is automatically selected by the system.

 

Enter the Reason of the Movement.

The reason can be configured in Transaction OMJJ for the Movement type 122.

 

Accounting Document After posting:

 

BSX Cr ‚Äì

WRX Dr +

Purchase Order History updates after Return.

 

The vendor sends the material as a subsequent replenishment of the damaged quantity as the subsequent delivery and we have to perform the GRN of the material.

Subsequent Delivery: The system prepopulate the return material document number, otherwise we can also locate the return delivery document number from the Purchase Order History.

Accounting Document after Vendor Return:

 

Updated PO History after GRN and MIRO:

Case 2: Return Process when Purchase Order not available.

Scenario: When a buyer procures books on a daily basis for a week and some of his books are not sold and the buyer wants to return the unsold books to the vendor.

Step 1:   In this case we have to create a Return Purchase Order. The Return Quantity & the Returns Item indicator has to be ticked.

 

Step 2: MIGO has to be performed. Choose Goods Receipt -> Purchase Order -> Enter the Purchase Order Number.

System automatically fetches the Movement Type 161 as Goods Return.

 

Enter the Quantity and Post.

Accounting Entries after Returns Posted -

 

BSX Cr-

WRX Dr+

Step 3: Issue of Credit Memo, Goto Transaction MIRO and enter the PO number as shown below, select Transaction- Credit memo.

Credit Memo Posted.

 

Updated Purchase Order History-

Conclusion: 

Vendor Returns can be done for goods received against a particular Purchase Order or for the extra stock that has to be returned to the supplier as excess supply. 

 

Regards,

Sagnik.

entry.title: Re: Compatibility Scope: What Happens after 2025/2030
entry.content:
Dear Prinya,
CJ20N itself is not part of compatibility packages, but only some sub-feature of CJ20N, such as hierachy graphics and others. Unfortunately, it is not possible to exactly check for the usage of these sub-features.
Therefore, we decided for CJ20N and similar other cases to check for the main transactions as indicator for possible feature usage in our tools such as Early Watch and Simplification Item Check even if these leads to false positives.
Generally, the outcome of these reports should be considered as indicators for compatibility package usage that must be double-checked with the affected business departments.

Best regards,
Stefan

entry.title: Re: How to load MDC Source tables?
entry.content:
Hi,

You can directly use BP webervice or a pure custom program to load data from other ecc system into MDC source tables and then trigger the MDC process automatically.

Please have a look at MDC standard BP save source table method: CL_MDC_BP_2_CONSOLIDATION~WRITE and BP trigger MDC Process method: CL_MDC_BP_2_CONSOLIDATION~START_PROCESS as a reference.

You can create a custom program to extract data from other ECC systems and then using above methods to save into MDC source tables and then trigger process.

 

Br.

Thomas

entry.title: SAP EHS Environment Management Process Outlining & Workflow
entry.content:
SAP EHS Environment Management Process Outlining

 Introduction:

The environment management application component helps companies to stay compliant with emissions-related environmental regulations. The solution covers the processes and sub-processes of managing compliance scenario activities to ensure compliance. These processes enable you to create and incorporate a strategy of managing environmentally related data from data collection, sampling, calculation, and aggregation of emissions into the daily operations within your companies.

  • Manage air and water emissions to fulfil legal requirements.
  • Calculate and aggregate emissions while fostering proactive data transparency and monitoring.
  • Detect and communicate deviations, manage investigations, and track follow-up activities.

How SAP EHS: Environment Management Helps Industry‚Äôs Today:

SAP's Environment Management product supports customers in the following ways:

  • Leverages prebuilt emission factor library and equations.
  • Collects activity data like fuel used, or electricity used.
  • Proactively flags data issues with data collection or emission calculations.
  • Monitors thresholds of greenhouse gas emissions.

Emission Management Process Steps:

The environment management application component helps companies to stay compliant with emissions-related environmental regulations (air and water emissions.) The solution covers the processes and sub-processes of managing compliance scenario activities to ensure compliance. These processes enable you to create and incorporate a strategy of managing environmentally relevant data from data collection, sampling, calculation, and aggregation of emissions into the daily operations within your company.

 

 

 

  1. Identify Compliance Requirements: The first step in the process is to identify and prepare the compliance requirements in the system. This is the task for the environment manager in the company. Inside a compliance requirement, its structure and content are modelled in a hierarchy of paragraphs with environmental limits, regulatory lists, and equations. They can be used later in the compliance scenario.

  2. Plan & Monitor Emissions: Once the compliance requirements are identified and created in the system, the environment manager can document all emissions-related activities into a compliance requirement. The next step in the process is that the environmental manager starts planning the emissions by creating and setting up the activities in the required compliance scenarios. The compliance scenario is the object that supports the execution of one or more compliance requirements. The main goal of a compliance scenario is to define and plan various types of activities, such as: Data collections (most of all emission data), Samplings (determining properties and compositions of used materials), Calculations (determining emissions from used materials), Location-based data aggregations, Execution of tasks.

  3. Collect & Sample Data: In the process steps Collect and Sample Data and Calculate and Aggregate Data, the environmental manager must perform the required steps to complete the planning. The respective compliance scenarios for the relevant locations must have been created beforehand.
    The Data Collection activity inside a Compliance Scenario defines the responsible persons who collect the emissions data. Also, the schedule of the data collection can be maintained.
    The Sampling activity inside a Compliance Scenario defines which substances or components to analyze (= analytes) and what sampling method to use for it.

  4. Calculate & Aggregate Data: Calculations determine amounts of gas emissions by using the amounts of incinerated materials (like coal or oil) collected earlier together with the emission factors that apply for those materials. More complicated calculations also exist. The environmental limits can optionally be referenced in a calculation.
    The environment manager can use this activity to acquire aggregated values for the environmental data; this aggregated data can be used for environmental assessments and for reporting to the authorities. The aggregation of data is done based on the location structure. These location-based aggregations use as input data collections, sampled data, and calculated data stored for your locations.

  5. Monitor Data & Identify Data Issues: In the process step, Monitor Data and Identify Data Issues, the environment manager can check the environmentally related data and identify if there are any issues with the data.
    The app can also be used to approve, replace, invalidate, and create deviations for data with warnings or for exceeded data.
    Collected and calculated data is automatically compared to associated limits in a compliance scenario and flagged, if exceeded.
    Limit warnings and exceedances are displayed in the Data Issues - Exceedances and Warning app.

  6. Identify Deviation: In the process step, Identify Deviations, the environmental manager starts monitoring the data on a plant level and performs checks against company goals about compliance with applicable environmental limits.
    A deviation record is an event that indicates the violation of specific environmental requirements.

  7. Record Deviation & Start Investigation: Once deviations have been identified, they can be created as records in the system, and a proper investigation can be performed and documented. The environmental manager can use this procedure to review and complete deviation records that have been created for inconsistent environmentally related data. During the review and completion process, you can check the information that is already available for the deviation and change it if necessary.

Conclusion:

The environment management application component helps companies to stay compliant with emissions-related environmental regulations. The solution covers the processes and sub-processes of managing compliance scenario activities to ensure compliance. These processes enable you to create and incorporate a strategy of managing environmentally related data from data collection, sampling, calculation, and aggregation of emissions into the daily operations within your companies.

 

Thankyou!

Regards 

Rampem Gourav

entry.title: Leveraging SAP SuccessFactors Compensation for Salary Benchmarking
entry.content:
Though SAP has brought in several enhancements in compensation module, there isn't a direct solution to capture external salary benchmarking data and use it for comparison against existing pay ranges during annual compensation planning activity. However for one of my recent client who is into new-gen technology product development, wanted to have their top talents (some even hold individual patents to their names)  paid as per market.

Client does have subscription tie-up with an external vendor who provides market salary data which the management would like to leverage during their annual compensation planning exercise. After understanding their business nuances, I did try to auto update EC custom MDF through an integration but it did not materialize due to platform differences and firewall incidents. So, I resorted to import the data to SuccessFactors until technical handshake happens between two platforms. Let me share the solution here, so that the tech savvy HR's can think of incorporating.  

How SuccessFactors Compensation Supports Market Benchmarking
SuccessFactors does not provide market data, however supports in creating placeholder for utilizing market benchmarking data and comparing it with existing pay ranges in Employee Central

  • Importing Market Data: Market benchmark data can be obtained from vendors such as Mercer, Aon, etc. and imported into SuccessFactors. It can be either imported directly in Employee Central leveraging custom fields or can be imported in a specific lookup table in compensation module with Country and Pay Grade being the key fields against which 'Min', 'Mid' & 'Max' values are maintained.
  • Salary Pay Matrix: Direct EC Pay Matrix can be used in order to compare with market data for a specific pay grade of a specific country. This enables the planner to consider the market pay data while making compensation decision for the employee.

Technical briefing from SuccessFactors standpoint:

  • A placeholder will be created for the market data to be imported into SF system. Could be custom fields in EC or through compensation lookup tables (preferred for non-EC system)
  • Create a section on the worksheet which populates the min-mid-max of market pay for the pay grade/country which helps the planner to compare current pay versus market pay for the employee and make compensation recommendations accordingly 
  • If the prospective market data provider (external vendor) can connect SF system, using their end point URL we can build a custom integration where the data is extracted automatically though a scheduled job and stored in custom MDF in Employee Central.

Companies are always reinventing and so do our clients, hence organizations to remain competitive in the talent market always go the extra mile to persuade. We shall support them in implementing such cost effective solutions and realize true value of their SAP investments.

SAP SuccessFactors Compensation SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

entry.title: Re: How to reverse ERS related goods receipt documents
entry.content:
Couple of ways are there to reverse ERS document
ERS invoices must be reversed by reversing the GR, not by canceling the invoice directly. Use the Post Goods Movement app or transaction MIGO. Select Movement Type 102 (Reversal of GR), Reference the original GR document, Ensure the quantity matches exactly. If you get M7021 Deficit PU IR Quantity, it means the invoice quantity has already been settled and the system blocks reversal.

To allow GR reversal even after invoice creation, you need to adjust customizing SPRO ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Inventory Management ‚Üí Goods Receipt ‚Üí Set ‚ÄúReversal of GR Despite Invoice‚Äù for Movement Type 102. This setting allows reversal of GR even if an ERS invoice exists. Check SAP Note 497178 explains this configuration.

Once the GR is successfully reversed, the ERS job will automatically create a cancellation invoice for the reversed GR. You do not need to manually reverse the invoice in MR8M.

entry.title: Re: How to create dynamic value help cds views for domain...
entry.content:
As you tought you can create a CDS view for the values:

@EndUserText.label: 'Get domain fix values'
@ObjectModel.resultSet.sizeCategory: #XS
@ObjectModel.dataCategory: #TEXT
define view entity ZIDomainFixValues 
  as select from    dd07l as FixedValue
    left outer join dd07t as ValueText on  FixedValue.domname    = ValueText.domname
                                       and FixedValue.domvalue_l = ValueText.domvalue_l
                                       and FixedValue.as4local   = ValueText.as4local

{
@UI.lineItem: [
  {
    importance: #LOW,
    value: 'DomainName',
    type: #STANDARD,
    position: 100,
    cssDefault.width: '1px'
  }
]
 @Consumption.valueHelpDefault.display:false 
key FixedValue.domname as DomainName,
@UI.hidden: true
key FixedValue.valpos as Valpos,
@UI.hidden: true
@Semantics.language: true
key  ValueText.ddlanguage as Language,
@UI.lineItem: [
  {
    importance: #HIGH,
    value: 'DomvalueL',
    type: #STANDARD,
    position: 20
  }
]
@Consumption.valueHelpDefault.display:true 
 FixedValue.domvalue_l as DomvalueL,

@UI.lineItem: [
  {
    importance: #HIGH,
    value: 'DomvalueH',
    type: #STANDARD,
    position: 30
  }
]
 FixedValue.domvalue_h as DomvalueH,
 .hidden: true
 FixedValue.appval as Appval,
@UI.lineItem: [
  {
    importance: #HIGH,
    value: 'DomeValueText',
    type: #STANDARD,
    position: 50
  }
]
@Consumption.valueHelpDefault.display:true 
@Semantics.text: true
 ValueText.ddtext as DomeValueText
}

where
      FixedValue.as4local  = 'A' --Active
  and ValueText.ddlanguage = $session.system_language

and then use it in other CDS views:

  @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{
  entity: {name: 'ZIDomainFixValues' , element: 'DomvalueL' },

  additionalBinding: [{ element: 'DomainName',
                           localConstant: 'ZSD_OUT_NP_FUNCTION', usage: #FILTER }],
                           distinctValues: true
                           }]
  @search.defaultSearchElement
  Function;

entry.title: How to calculate depreciation for multiple capitalizations across years in SAC?
entry.content:
Hi all,

I'm working on a CAPEX planning model in SAP Analytics Cloud, and doing depreciation logic where multiple capitalizations happen in different years, each with their own timeline, but they all sum up into the fixed asset value and depreciate based on their own start date.

I don‚Äôt have a dedicated "capitalization year" field, only the date dimension (e.g., FY, period). I‚Äôm looking to:

  1. Accumulate the Fixed Asset value based on the total capitalized until that year.

  2. Calculate depreciation per year for each capitalized amount based on the useful life (e.g., straight-line method).

  3. Ensure that the depreciation logic respects the start year of each capitalized amount and stops after its life ends.

 Below is the code I am having and results attached in screenshot. Thanks

FOREACH.BOOKED [d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT]
 
//get the total budget
@TOTALBUDGET = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount", [d/Account] = "CAPEX_003", [d/Date] = PERIOD([d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/BUDGETEDYEAR]))
//get the previous year spending
@PYSPENDING = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "Amount", [d/Account] = "CAPEX_012", [d/Date] = "2022")
//calculate remaining budget
@REMAININGBUDGET = ROUND(@TOTALBUDGET - @PYSPENDING, 3)
//calculate the annual depreciation
@ANNUALDEPR = ROUND(@REMAININGBUDGET / @USEFULLIFE, 2)
@ENERGIZEDYEAR = ATTRIBUTE([d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/ENERGIZEDYEAR])
@YEAR_COUNT = 0
@count = INT(@USEFULLIFE)
 
FOREACH [d/Date]
//get the energized year
//DATA([d/Account] = #ENERGYEAR_VAL, [d/DIM_AUDIT] = "#", [d/DIM_BUDGETYEAR] = "#", [d/DIM_FLOW] = "#", [d/DIM_SCENARIO] = "#", [d/Measures] = "Amount") = ATTRIBUTE([d/DIM_WBS_PROJECT].[p/ENERGIZEDYEAR])
// Read year of this Date member
@Number = @ENERGIZEDYEAR - @BUDEGTYEAR + 1
@CURRYEAR = YEAR([d/Date])
IF @CURRYEAR <= @ENERGIZEDYEAR AND @REMAININGBUDGET > 0 THEN
//BOOK the annual spending
DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_001") = ROUND(@REMAININGBUDGET / @Number, 6)
//BOOK CWIP
DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_012") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_012",[d/Date]=PREVIOUS(1)) + RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_001")
//Fixed Assets
DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_007") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_007",[d/Date]=PREVIOUS(1))+RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_002")
//CWIP Final
DATA( [d/Account] = "CAPEX_013") = RESULTLOOKUP( [d/Account] = "CAPEX_013",[d/Date]=PREVIOUS(1))+ RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_001")-RESULTLOOKUP( [d/Account] = "CAPEX_002")
ENDIF
@CAPITALIZED = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_002")
FOR @start_COUNT = 1 TO @count
DATA([d/Account] = "CAPEX_004",[d/Date] = NEXT(@START_COUNT)) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "CAPEX_007") /@USEFULLIFE
ENDFOR

entry.title: How to Automate Multi Action Execution via REST API (Server-Side) without User Interaction?
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I have a question regarding the automation of processes using the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) REST API.

What I want to achieve:

I am trying to call the SAC REST API from a server-side application (e.g., Python, Node.js) to execute a specific Multi Action in a fully automated manner. The target API endpoint is: /api/v1/multiActions/{multiActionId}/execute

Current Situation and Challenges:

To handle authentication for the API call, I have created an OAuth 2.0 client from the SAC administration menu (System > Administration).

My first attempt was to create a client with the "Interactive Usage" purpose. However, based on the documentation, I understand that this purpose requires a redirect URI for user authentication and consent. This approach seems designed for scenarios where a web application acts on behalf of a user.

This has led to the following challenge:

Because user interaction (logging in and clicking the consent screen in a browser) is required, it is difficult to create a completely automated, server-to-server batch process.

My Questions:

  • Is there a recommended solution for calling the Multi Action execution API from a server-side application as a batch process, without any user interaction?
  • I also tried creating an OAuth client with the "API Access" purpose, but I could not get it to work. If this is the correct approach, could you please provide guidance on the proper configuration or point out potential reasons for failure (e.g., missing permissions)?
  • Alternatively, is there a fundamental misunderstanding in my approach to automating SAC API calls?

I have managed to successfully obtain an OAuth token using the "API Access" purpose. However, when I use this token to call the API in my execute_multi_action method, the request fails with a 500 Internal Server Error.

Here is the sample Python code that demonstrates the issue. The get_oauth_token and get_csrf_token function works correctly, but the execute_multi_action function receives the 500 error.

import requests
import json

# Constants for authentication and API endpoints (masked for security)
TOKEN_URL = "https://<MASKED>.authentication.<MASKED>.ondemand.com/oauth/token"
SAC_BASE = "https://<MASKED>.analytics.cloud.sap"
CLIENT_ID = '<MASKED_CLIENT_ID>'
CLIENT_SECRET = '<MASKED_CLIENT_SECRET>'
MULTI_ACTION_ID = '<MASKED_MULTI_ACTION_ID>'

def get_bearer_token():
    """
    Obtain OAuth2 bearer token using client credentials grant.
    """
    resp = requests.post(
        TOKEN_URL,
        auth=(CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SECRET),
        data={'grant_type': 'client_credentials'}
    )
    resp.raise_for_status()  # Raise an error for HTTP error codes
    return resp.json()['access_token']

def get_csrf_token(session, bearer_token):
    """
    Retrieve CSRF token required for subsequent API requests.
    """
    url = f"{SAC_BASE}/api/v1/csrf"
    headers = {
        'x-csrf-token': 'fetch',                # Request to fetch CSRF token
        'x-sap-sac-custom-auth': 'true',
        'Authorization': f"Bearer {bearer_token}",
    }
    # Send GET request to retrieve CSRF token
    resp = session.get(url, headers=headers)
    resp.raise_for_status()
    csrf_token = resp.headers.get('x-csrf-token')
    print(f"CSRF Token: {csrf_token}")
    return csrf_token

def execute_multi_action(session, bearer_token, csrf_token):
    """
    Execute a multi-action via SAC API with required parameters.
    """
    url = f"{SAC_BASE}/api/v1/multiActions/{MULTI_ACTION_ID}/executions"
    headers = {
        'x-csrf-token': csrf_token,
        'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        'x-sap-sac-custom-auth': 'true',
        'Authorization': f"Bearer {bearer_token}",
    }
    payload = {
        "parameterValues": [
            {
                "parameterId": "TargetVersion",
                "value": {
                    "memberIds": ["public.Plan_TEST"],
                    "hierarchyId": None
                }
            },
            {
                "parameterId": "SourceVersion",
                "value": {
                    "memberIds": ["public.Actual"],
                    "hierarchyId": None
                }
            }
        ]
    }
    # Send POST request to execute the multi-action
    resp = session.post(url, headers=headers, data=json.dumps(payload))
    resp.raise_for_status()
    return resp.json()["executionId"]

def get_execution_result(session, execution_id):
    """
    Retrieve the result or status of the executed multi-action.
    """
    url = f"{SAC_BASE}/api/v1/multiActions/{MULTI_ACTION_ID}/executions/{execution_id}"
    # Send GET request to get execution result
    resp = session.get(url)
    resp.raise_for_status()
    return resp.json()

def main():
    # Step 1: Obtain bearer token for authentication
    bearer_token = get_bearer_token()
    with requests.Session() as session:
        # Step 2: Get CSRF token for secure API requests
        csrf_token = get_csrf_token(session, bearer_token)
        print("Current cookies in session:")
        for cookie in session.cookies:
            print(f"{cookie.name} = {cookie.value}")

        # Prepare cookie string for use in headers (if needed)
        cookie_string = "; ".join([f"{c.name}={c.value}" for c in session.cookies])
        print("Cookie string for headers:")
        print(cookie_string)

        # Step 3: Execute the multi-action and get its execution ID
        execution_id = execute_multi_action(session, bearer_token, csrf_token)
        # Step 4: Retrieve and print the execution result
        result = get_execution_result(session, execution_id)
        print(json.dumps(result, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

Thank you for your time and assistance.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere - Replication Flow (Delta Functionality)
entry.content:
HI @RAviraj3 ,
If you have following annotations on your CDS view that you created on S4 systems, the system will use automatic delta capture using CDC once you create replication flow in SAP Datasphere with "initial and delta" settings for the CDS view. 

@Analytics.dataExtraction.enabled:true

@Analytics.dataExtraction.delta.changeDataCapture.automatic: true

Please note that you need all SAP DI related TCI Notes implemented on your S4 system to support this. Also, if you have a very complex logic in your CDS views the CDC automatic delta will not work. Hope this helps!

entry.title: Re: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public edition unable to deactiv...
entry.content:
Hello @Rohit0909 ,

Thanks for the detailed update.

You've confirmed that:

  • The Create Inbound Delivery app is included only in catalog SAP_LE_BC_ID_PROC_MC
  • The catalog supports IAM-based app control
  • You‚Äôve removed and reassigned roles to trigger a refresh

However, the app is still visible, which typically means the catalog is still indirectly assigned through another role.

Recommended Next Steps:

  • Review all assigned roles for the user IAM permissions are cumulative. The app may still be exposed via another role containing the same catalog.
  • Use the Refresh IAM Authorizations action in the Maintain Business Roles app to re-sync backend assignments.
  • Clear cache or use Incognito Mode to eliminate tile caching issues.

If the issue persists, raise an SAP incident under CA-IAM-ABA.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Is there any way to trigger the data update in tables...

Even with correct settings, if it is not working as expected, it could be due to:

  • Update program not triggered immediately
  • Missing update rules or routines
  • Background job dependencies

In such cases, consider running program RMCBNEUA to force update, checking update rules in MC24, verifying update groups in MC26

entry.title: FB60 Duplicate invoices are not checked anymore
entry.content:
Hello experts,

In my system S4, FB60 Duplicate invoices are not checked anymore. before the check was working fine.

Now I checked, if the fields relevants for this check have been updated or changer, but it seems that there no way to change them, it's the standard behavior of SAP :

If the Reference Document Number field (BKPF-XBLNR) is filled up the following fields will be checked to idnetify duplicate invoices:

  • Company Code(BUKRS)
  • Vendor(LIFNR)
  • Currency(WAERS)
  • Invoice/Document Date(BLDAT)
  • Reference document number(XBLNR)

If the Reference Document Number field (BKPF-XBLNR) is not filled up the following fields will be checked to idnetify duplicate invoices:

  • Company Code(BUKRS)
  • Vendor(LIFNR)
  • Currency(WAERS)
  • Invoice/Document Date(BLDAT)
  • Amount in document currency(WRBTR)

Can you please confirm this ?

Now, what other points can I check ?

May be make a debug with a developer to make to check if there is a specific ABAP that bypass this check ?

 

Thank you for your help

Regards,

entry.title: Handling CKEditor Content Sanitization and Formatting Issues in SAP Commerce SmartEdit
entry.content:
Background

SAP Commerce SmartEdit uses CKEditor for editing CMSParagraphComponent content. CKEditor includes sanitization logic that strips or modifies HTML tags it considers unsafe. If HTML is not well-formatted during in imported impex file  , SmartEdit may:

  • Remove content completely.

  • Alter the layout unintentionally.

  • Break visual rendering inside the editing UI.

Common Issues Observed

  • Special tags like <div>, <style>, or <script> disappear when editing a paragraph component.

  • HTML imported via impex with malformed tags (e.g., missing closing tags, extra <br> or  ) leads to distortion.

  • Changes made in SmartEdit on top of malformed HTML worsen the structure and cause further rendering issues.

CKEditor Sanitization Configuration

SAP Commerce allows limited control over this behavior using the following property:

 
cms.components.allowUnsafeJavaScript=true

Enabling this property allows SmartEdit to preserve certain script or inline JavaScript blocks, but this alone is not enough. If the underlying HTML is inconsistent or dirty, CKEditor still might misinterpret it.

Solution ‚Äì Groovy Script to Clean and Beautify HTML

If a significant amount of CMSParagraphComponent content has already been maintained in a higher environment via Impex imports, issues may arise when a business user opens and edits that content through the SmartEdit editor. In such cases, saving the changes can distort the view of the content. This often happens because the imported HTML may contain formatting issues, such as unnecessary line breaks or improperly structured tags.

To address this, one option is to manually clean up the HTML formatting in each Impex file. However, a more efficient solution is to use the Groovy script provided below. This script exports all CMSParagraphComponent content from the higher environment, cleans up the HTML formatting, and prepares a clean Impex file that can be re-imported into the target catalog. Once the Impex is imported and the sync process is completed, the display issues in SmartEdit should be resolved.

Groovy Script :  

import de.hybris.platform.core.Registry
import de.hybris.platform.catalog.CatalogVersionService
import de.hybris.platform.cms2.model.contents.components.CMSParagraphComponentModel
import de.hybris.platform.servicelayer.model.ModelService
import de.hybris.platform.servicelayer.search.FlexibleSearchService

// Initialize required services
def modelService = spring.getBean("modelService", ModelService)
def searchService = spring.getBean("flexibleSearchService", FlexibleSearchService)
def catalogVersionService = spring.getBean("catalogVersionService", CatalogVersionService)
def commonI18NService = spring.getBean("commonI18NService")

// Define language and catalog context
def languageIso = "en" // Replace with desired language ISO
def catalogId = "abcContentCatalog" // Replace with your catalog ID
def catalogVersion = "Staged" // Replace with your catalog version

// Set the current language
def lang = commonI18NService.getLanguage(languageIso)
commonI18NService.setCurrentLanguage(lang)

// Get catalog version model
def catalogVersionModel = catalogVersionService.getCatalogVersion(catalogId, catalogVersion)

// Query CMSParagraphComponent items
def query = """
    SELECT {pk} FROM {CMSParagraphComponent}
    WHERE {catalogVersion} = ?catalogVersion
"""
def params = ["catalogVersion": catalogVersionModel]
def result = searchService.search(query, params)

// Print Impex header
println "INSERT_UPDATE CMSParagraphComponent;uid[unique=true];catalogVersion(catalog(id),version)[unique=true];content[lang=${languageIso}]"

// Process each component and beautify content
result.result.each { CMSParagraphComponentModel component ->
    def content = component.getContent()
    if (content != null) {
        def beautifiedContent = beautifyHtml(content)
        println ";${component.uid};${catalogId}:${catalogVersion};\"${beautifiedContent}\""
    }
}

// HTML Beautification Helper
def beautifyHtml(String html) {
    if (!html) return ""

    // Step 1: Normalize tag breaks
    html = html.replaceAll("><", ">\n<")

    // Step 2: Remove leading spaces on each line
    html = html.replaceAll("(?m)^\\s+", "")

    // Step 3: Clean up attributes inside tags
    html = html.replaceAll(/<([^>]+)>/) { full, inner ->
        def cleaned = inner.replaceAll(/[\n\r]+/, " ") // Remove newlines
                           .replaceAll(/\s+/, " ")     // Collapse extra spaces
                           .trim()
        return "<${cleaned}>"
    }

    // Step 4: Normalize inner text between tags
    html = html.replaceAll(/>([^<]+)</) { full, inner ->
        def cleaned = inner.replaceAll(/[\n\r]+/, " ")
                           .replaceAll(/\s+/, " ")
                           .trim()
        return ">" + cleaned + "<"
    }

    // Step 5: Re-indent HTML
    def indent = 0
    def lines = html.split("\n")
    def indented = lines.collect { line ->
        if (line =~ /^<\/.+>/) indent--
        def result = "  " * Math.max(indent, 0) + line.trim()
        if (line =~ /^<[^\/!][^>]*[^\/]>$/ && !(line =~ /<.*<\/.*>/)) indent++
        return result
    }

    // Step 6: Escape double quotes for Impex
    return indented.join("\n").replaceAll('"', '""')
}

What the Script Does:

  • Cleans malformed HTML tags and unnecessary line breaks

  • Fixes spacing and re-indents the content for improved readability and structure

  • Escapes double quotes to ensure compatibility with Impex format

Sample Output:

Here‚Äôs a sample output generated by the script in Impex format:

INSERT_UPDATE CMSParagraphComponent;uid[unique=true];catalogVersion(catalog(id),version)[unique=true];content[lang=en]
;AboutUsPageParagraphComponent;abcContentCatalog:Staged;"<div class=""container""><div class=""row small-health-container""><div class=""main__text-container header-text mt-10""><h3 class=""title mb-20"">Wherever you are on your health journey!</h3><p class=""description""><span>Dis-Chem goes beyond being just a pharmacy and retail store;</span>we deliver healthcare in various ways, extending our services, products, and initiatives to encompass community clinics, feeding programs the Dis-Chem Foundation, and health insurance products. With the momentum of initiatives like these driving Dis-Chem forward, we hope to lead a movement in South Africa, becoming the champions of better health for all. This shift in perspective allows us to see the bigger picture and take a more holistic view of health and wellness in today‚Äôs world. It aligns with the growth of our offerings, which we have developed and implemented over the years.</p><p class=""description mt-20""><span>Continuing to prioritize the bigger picture and adopting a holistic view of health and wellness will undoubtedly have a positive impact on our customers and the communities we serve. We are inspired by the opportunity to make a difference in people‚Äôs lives beyond the traditional role of a pharmacy and retail store.</span></p><div><hr></div></div></div></div>"

Conclusion:

CKEditor‚Äôs sanitization, while important for security, can interfere with business HTML requirements if the input content is malformed. Combining SmartEdit configuration (cms.components.allowUnsafeJavaScript=true) with Groovy-based content cleanup ensures your CMS content is resilient, editable, and production-ready.

entry.title: Re: Non-Nettable Warehouse Inventory Calculated in ATP
entry.content:
ATP in SAP ECC/S4HANA by default ignores the ‚Äúnettable‚Äù indicator on warehouses and sums all unrestricted stock at plant level. MRP runs honor the nettable flag, but classic ATP doesn‚Äôt. In SPRO (or the equivalent SSCUI in S/4HANA Cloud) under Sales and Distribution > Basic Functions > Availability Check you can create/modify your Scope of Check, assign it to your Checking Rule/Checking Group, tick ‚ÄúNo storage location inspection‚Äù. This tells the ATP engine to ignore storage-location stock entirely and only consider slocs entered on the sales order. Limitation: if no sloc is entered on the order, ATP still returns total plant stock (including sloc 04).

If you prefer a purely configuration-only approach, then, define an MRP Area type 02 for storage location 04. Assign sloc 04 to that MRP Area. In your ATP scope, restrict checks to all MRP Areas except the one for sloc 04. This isolates non-nettable stock but adds overhead on master-data maintenance and MRP runs.

The below comparison table will give a better idea

entry.title: How to Activate the Alert Management and Job & Automation Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM?
entry.content:
Hi Team,

How to we change the settings in the "Supported Use Cases" section of a system entry in the SAP Cloud ALM Landscape Management app? The "Job & Automation Monitoring" entry has configuration status "Inactive", and the "Alert Management" has status "Not Configured". How do we enable these settings? 

Thanks


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to Activate the Alert Management and Job & Automa...
entry.content:
If a system in the SAP Cloud ALM Landscape Management app has Configuration Status value "Inactive", it means that data collection was enabled at one point, but has been disabled and the SAP Cloud ALM backend still has collected data for that system. If you wish to move the status to "Active", you simply must enable data collection again for that system. More information can be found in KBA 3616000.

The "Alerting Management" statuses are dependent on the settings in the SAP Cloud ALM for Operations use cases. In order for "Alert Management" to show Active statuses, at least 1 Operations use case must have an event that generates alerts for the specified system. If no alerting has been enabled for a system, the use case "Alerting Management" will continue to show status "Not Configured". You spoke about Job & Automation Monitoring, so you can follow KBA 3111904 to help configure Alerting for that use case.

entry.title: Re: SAC Odata Service Connection Failed
Re: FB60 Duplicate invoices are not checked anymore
entry.content:
By design, the FI duplicate-invoice check in FB60 (and F-43/MIRO) uses the following fields:

When Reference Number (BKPF‚ÄìXBLNR) is filled, it checks Company Code (BUKRS) ‚Ä¢ Vendor (LIFNR) ‚Ä¢ Currency (WAERS) ‚Ä¢ Invoice/Document Date (BLDAT) ‚Ä¢ Reference Document Number (XBLNR)

When Reference Number is blank it checks Company Code (BUKRS) ‚Ä¢ Vendor (LIFNR) ‚Ä¢ Currency (WAERS) ‚Ä¢ Invoice/Document Date (BLDAT) ‚Ä¢ Amount in Document Currency (WRBTR).

Use transaction BP (or FK02 for classic vendor master) ‚Üí role FLVN00 ‚Üí Payment Transactions view ‚Üí ensure Check double inv. (LFB1‚ÄìREPRF) is selected. If this flag is off, FB60 skips the duplicate check.

Go to SPRO ‚Üí Financial Accounting Global Settings ‚Üí Document ‚Üí Default Values for Document Processing ‚Üí Change Message Control for Document Processing. Under Application Area F5 (General Data) and M8 (Transactional Data), locate message F5 117. Ensure it‚Äôs set as a warning or error, not ‚Äúblank.‚Äù If it‚Äôs blank, SAP won‚Äôt intervene‚Äîeven if the FM finds a duplicate.

Open transaction OB41, select the posting key used by FB60 (e.g., 21). Check the ‚ÄúSales-related posting‚Äù indicator. Only posting keys flagged here trigger the duplicate-invoice logic.

entry.title: Re: Reduce height of combo box drop down
entry.content:
Hi,

For sap.m.ComboBox, there are some sap build in css capabilty.

You can use this "sapMComboBoxList" sap ui5 standard css class to reduce height of your comboBox. Note: size 30 rem will show you 10 items at a time and rest items by scrolling. If you use sap.m.Select you need upgrade it to sap.m.ComboBox, as this is for holding long list of items.

.sapMComboBoxList {
max-height: 30rem;
scroll-behavior: smooth;
}

Also if you use sap.m.MultiComboBox then use the below sap ui5 standard css class :

.sapMListItems {
max-height: 20rem;
}

I have implemented this approach to reduce the height of dropdown in sap ui5. It was really challenging to figure out this approach.

Thanks,

Shobhit Srivastava

SAP BTP developer

entry.title: How to Design Low-Fidelity Dashboards with the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit
entry.content:
Focus of this blog:

  1. Intro
  2. How the library is set up
  3. How to get the library
  4. How to use the library
  5. How to work efficiently with the library

 

Intro

Effective dashboard design begins with user research. Gathering and understanding the necessary insights of your end-user‚Äôs needs and requirements ensures high-quality experience. Jumping straight into creating high-fidelity mockups or even building dashboards directly in SAC Stories can create unnecessary distraction and slow down your design process.

üëâLearn how to build better dashboards here.

Instead, start with scribbles and rough sketches. Early in the process, low-fidelity mockups help you explore ideas quickly, collect feedback, and align on structure and meaningful insights before refining visual details.

That‚Äôs why we created the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit for Figma. It helps you transform your ideas seamlessly into digital high-level, low-fidelity designs.

The library offers basic layouts and provides components to help you design and iterate quickly, without distraction, ensuring you can focus on what matters: Content, Flow, and Meaningful Insights. It helps you to speed up your design process, share clear ideas, review them with your team, and get feedback from stakeholders.

 

 

How the library is set up

The library consists of three pages, which allows for easy navigation and usage.

The first page: ‚Äúüìì Cover‚Äú, is a library overview that includes a cover, a version history and slides explaining the purpose and usage of the library.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The second page: ‚Äú‚úèÔ∏è Analytical Pages‚Äù, provides Dashboard Templates. Depending on the purpose of your dashboard, you can choose to use a Reporting, Planning or Monitoring Page Type, or start with an Empty Page to design your dashboard from scratch.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The third page: ‚Äú‚úèÔ∏è Components‚Äù, contains all other assets: UI elements and controls, containers and different chart types available in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

How to get the library

You can simply download the library from GitHub.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Opening the file will import it into Figma. Just choose a folder, and you're ready to go.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

üëâDownload the SAC Dashboard Schematics UI Kit on GitHub.

 

 

How to use the library

We recommend publishing the library internally after importing the file to make use of Figma‚Äôs Library functionality. This means, that based on your settings, your direct team or your whole organization can access the library through the asset panel, enabling smooth collaboration and consistent usage across your design teams.

To publish a library, open the File Settings, navigate to ‚ÄúLibrary‚Äù and click on ‚ÄúPublish Library...‚Äù. Select the components you want to publish and specify who can access the library. Click on "Publish" and it's done.

Note: This option won't work if the file has been imported into your Drafts.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Now you can add the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit to your files through the libraries dialog and access all components directly from the assets panel.

If you don‚Äôt want to publish the library internally, you can simply copy and paste the components into your own design files or use them as local assets.

 

 

How to work efficiently with the library

To get started, we‚Äôve created a short introduction video that demonstrates how to build a dashboard using the library.

 

You can follow one of two possible workflows:

1. Start with an Analytical Page Type

Open a new file and navigate to the assets panel. Drag an instance into your canvas, e.g. a Monitoring Page.

In the design panel, you can see the different options you have for each instance. The Monitoring Page can use the visual type ‚ÄúPlaceholder‚Äù (default) or ‚ÄúContent‚Äù. Switching to ‚ÄúContent‚Äù will present basic charts.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Most Components are nested within each other. This means you can simply select individual parts of an instance to get additional options in the design panel. This makes it easy to adjust the layout to fit your specific needs.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

2. Start from Scratch

Open a new file and either create a new frame or navigate to the assets panel to drag an Empty Page into your canvas. If you use the Empty Page, you can detach the instance to freely use and customize the frame.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Browse or search for the containers you want to use, e.g. a Header and multiple Panels or Cards, and drag them into your frame.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Set Visual Type to ‚ÄúContent‚Äù to show charts.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Feel free to comment any feedback, ideas, questions or requests you have for our SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit.

And check out our Dashboard Design Best-Practices blog series, that was created to assist you in designing and building meaningful dashboards with SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: INSERT/DELETE data in exposed CDS entities via ODBC
entry.content:
In previous blog posts (see links at the end), I described data integration scenarios where business users can access data in an ABAP system from an external consumer, using the ABAP SQL service and the ODBC driver for ABAP. In this scenario, can query data in exposed CDS view entities. So far, this was a read-only scenario, where SELECT statements were used.

Now, with the availability of writable CDS view entities, the SQL service can also be used to change data in an ABAP system. The first supported SQL DML statements that allow to change data in an SAP system using the ABAP SQL service are INSERT and DELETE.

In this blog post, I will describe an example where a writable ABAP CDS view entity is exposed, I will describe the supported INSERT and DELETE statement types and their restrictions, and provide a code sample that uses those statements on an exposed entity.

Prerequisites:

  • ABAP platform cloud 2508 or ABAP on-premise 2025 or higher
  • ODBC driver for ABAP version 01, or higher

The steps to expose a writable view entity are very similar to the steps described in this blog post for read-only entities. I will try to keep the description in this blog post similar and only outline the differences for writable CDS view entities.

Create a Writable CDS View Entity on Top of a Table

First, I create a test table for this blog post and a writable CDS view entity on top of it. In my case, the writable view entity is a simple projection of a database test table containing all table columns.

@EndUserText.label : 'test table for SQL Service DMLs'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zsql_write_tab {
  key client : abap.clnt not null;
  key itemnr : abap.int4 not null;
  key idate  : abap.datn not null;
  @AbapCatalog.decfloat.outputStyle : #NORMAL
  amount     : abap.decfloat34;
}

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'writable view entity for SQL service'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
  serviceQuality: #X,
  sizeCategory: #S,
  dataClass: #MIXED
}
define writable view entity ZSQL_WRITE_VIEW
  as select from zsql_write_tab as TestTable
{
  key itemnr as ItemNr,
  key idate  as IDate,
  amount     as Amount
}

Create a service definition and binding containing the writable CDS view entity

As a second step, define a service definition exposing the writable view entity:

@EndUserText.label: 'service def with writable view entity'

define service ZWRITE
  provider contracts sql {
  expose ZSQL_WRITE_VIEW as WriteView;
}

I create a service binding with the same name as the service definition and enable operations. Please note that I enabled operations SELECT, INSERT, and DELETE for this service binding:

 

Configure Privileged User Access with INSERT and DELETE Operations

Next, I define the user access to the writable CDS view entities. Again, the configuration of privileged user access has already been described in this blog post for a cloud system, or you can refer to the onprem documentation. INSERT and DELETE statements are currently only allowed for privileged user access.

So, essentially, you can follow the previous blog post. The only difference is that you now need to add INSERT and DELETE as allowed SQL view operations to the S_SQL_VIEW authorization object, for example, with the following properties.

SQL_SCHEMA -> ZWRITE
SQL_VIEW -> *
SQL_VIEWOP -> SELECT, INSERT, DELETE

Now, everything is set up to execute queries and INSERT and DELETE statements on our test entity.
I won‚Äôt repeat the description of how to install and configure the ODBC driver for ABAP here and for the next steps I will just assume that this is done and that you configured an ODBC DSN for your SAP system. For all details about installing and configuring the ODBC driver for ABAP, check my previous blog posts.

Now let‚Äôs turn to the SQL statements INSERT and DELETE and how they are supported in the SQL service.

The INSERT Statement in the SQL Dialect of the ABAP SQL Service

Compared to ABAP SQL, the SQL dialect of the SQL service has a few restrictions and specialties that  you must consider.

INSERT ‚Ä¶ VALUES and INSERT ‚Ä¶ SELECT statements are supported.

The supported INSERT ‚Ä¶ VALUES statements have the following form:

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view> VALUES ( <expression1>, <expression2>, ‚Ä¶)

Compared to other databases, currently there is no column list clause supported. The maximum number of expressions in the VALUES clause is the number of columns in the exposed entity. If you provide fewer expressions, the last columns in the writable entity will be set to their default database values during INSERT.

Expressions can be simple literals, expressions containing functions, or parameter markers ( ‚Äò?‚Äô ) for prepared statements.
For literals or expressions, the types need to be compatible with the DDIC data types of exposed entity. This requires CASTs in some cases.

INSERT ‚Ä¶ SELECT statements have the following form:

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view> <ABAP SQL service SQL query>‚Äã

where <ABAP SQL service SQL query> is a SELECT statement in the SQL dialect of the SQL service.
Currently, the <ABAP SQL service SQL query> cannot contain common table expressions (CTEs starting with the keyword ‚ÄúWITH‚Äù).

Again, the number of columns in the result set of the SELECT statement must match the number of columns in the exposed entity, and the data types returned by the SELECT statement need to be compatible with the data types of the exposed entity.

The following INSERT statements are equivalent:

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view> VALUES ( <expression1>, <expression2>, ‚Ä¶)

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view> SELECT <expression1>, <expression2>, ‚Ä¶ FROM SYS.DUMMY

The SYS.DUMMY trick can also be used to formulate some kind of simple SQL array INSERT:

INSERT INTO <schema>.<view>
  SELECT <expression1a>, <expression2a>, ‚Ä¶ FROM SYS.DUMMY
  UNION ALL
  SELECT <expression1b>, <expression2b>, ‚Ä¶ FROM SYS.DUMMY
  ‚Ä¶

 I will discuss the more efficient ODBC array input method using an INSERT statement with parameter markers later with a python ODBC code sample. However, keep in mind that some ODBC tools do not support SQL statements with parameter markers or some language plugins like the node.js ODBC plugin currently do not allow to use ODBC array INSERT.

The DELETE Statement in the SQL Dialect of the ABAP SQL Service

Simple DELETE statements with or without WHERE clauses are supported.

DELETE FROM  <schema>.<view>  <WHERE-clause>

where  <WHERE-clause> can be any WHERE clause that can be used in a corresponding query (‚ÄúSELECT FROM  <schema>.<view>  <WHERE-clause>‚Äù).

Bundling Multiple DML Statements in one Database Transaction

For the first time, the ABAB SQL service now supports DML statements, but it still does not provide an option for explicit transaction handling. This means that the ODBC driver for ABAP always works in auto commit mode and does not support explicit commits and rollbacks.

This implies that all DML statements are automatically committed after each successful execution. On the other hand, all changes of a DML statement execution are automatically rolled back after an error occurs.

The other way to bundle multiple row changes in a single database transaction is the use of array input for ODBC execution using DML statements with parameter markers.  Again, the ODBC execution with array input is atomically committed on success or rolled back after an error.

Without explicit transaction handling, multiple different DML statements cannot be bundled in one database transaction.

DML examples without Parameter Markers Using iusql

I will now provide some DML examples on our test entity using the simple iusql command line tool included in the Linux unixODBC package ( see my Linux blog post). This is just an arbitrary example of a tool that does not support SQL statements with parameter markers. As an alternative, you could, for example, use a Java-based tool like DBeaver or Squirrel with a suitable JDBC/ODBC bridge for the ODBC driver for ABAP.

In this example, the following happens:

  • An INSERT ‚Ä¶ VALUES statement is used to insert the first row into our test entity
  • Some INSERT ‚Ä¶ SELECT statements are used to generate more test data with ascending ItemNr and IDate
  • A DELETE ‚Ä¶ WHERE is used to delete a first set of rows
  • A subsequent DELETE is used to clean up the table

> iusql -v MYDSN

+---------------------------------------+
| Connected!                            |
|                                       |
| sql-statement                         |
| help [tablename]                      |
| quit                                  |
|                                       |
+---------------------------------------+

SQL> delete from ZWRITE.WriteView

SQLRowCount returns 0

SQL> insert into ZWRITE.WriteView
     values( 1 , date '2015-01-01' , CAST( 100 AS DECIMAL)  )

SQLRowCount returns 1

SQL> INSERT INTO ZWRITE.WriteView
     select MAX(VMAX.ItemNr) + V.ItemNr ,
     DATN_ADD_DAYS( V.IDate, MAX(VMAX.ItemNr) ) ,
     V.Amount
     from ZWRITE.WriteView V ,
          ZWRITE.WriteView VMAX
     group by V.ItemNr , V.IDate, V.Amount

SQLRowCount returns 1

SQL> repeat ‚Ä¶ INSERT INTO

SQLRowCount returns 2

SQL> repeat ‚Ä¶ INSERT INTO

SQLRowCount returns 4

SQL> repeat ‚Ä¶ INSERT INTO

SQLRowCount returns 8

SQL> repeat ‚Ä¶ INSERT INTO ‚Ä¶ make sure that you do not repeat this too often

SQLRowCount returns 16

SQL> select ItemNr, IDate FROM ZWRITE.WriteView

+------------+---------+
| ItemNr     | IDate   |
+------------+---------+
| 1          | 20150101|
| 2          | 20150102|
| 3          | 20150103|
| ‚Ä¶                    |
| 19         | 20150119|
| 20         | 20150120|
| 21         | 20150121|
| ‚Ä¶                    |
| 31         | 20150131|
| 32         | 20150201|
+------------+---------+

SQLRowCount returns 0

32 rows fetched

SQL> delete from ZWRITE.WriteView where IDate < date '2015-01-20'

SQLRowCount returns 19

SQL> delete from ZWRITE.WriteView

SQLRowCount returns 13


DML Array Input Examples Using a Python Sample

ODBC supports using prepared statements multiple times. Prepared statements with parameter markers can be executed with an array input, allowing to execute the same prepared statement multiple times with a different set of input parameters in one network roundtrip. For the ODBC driver for ABAP, this also means that such statement executions with array input will be performed in one database transaction and all statement executions will be committed or rolled back together.

Native ODBC C code can easily become lengthy and is not well suited for demo purposes. Therefore, like in one of my previous blog posts about AMDP procedures, I will provide a Python code sample here. Python demo code is much more compact and easier to read and understand. The Python ODBC plugin called pyodbc supports ODBC array input. A more detailed introduction to this ODBC plugin has already been provided in this Python blog post .

The following Python sample code:

  • Inserts some rows with an INSERT ‚Ä¶ VALUES statement with parameter markers
  • Doubles the number of rows with an INSERT ‚Ä¶ SELECT statement
  • Deletes some rows with an array DELETE statement with parameter markers

A subsequent DELETE is used to clean up the table

Please note fast_executemany=True used for the array statement. This ensures that the array data is sent to the ABAP backend in one package and that the array operation is performed in one database transaction.

import pyodbc
import getpass
import datetime
# some docu in
# https://code.google.com/archive/p/pyodbc/wikis/GettingStarted.wiki
# https://github.com/mkleehammer/pyodbc/wiki
#
# install pyodbc before running the program 
# "pip install pyodbc"
#
# run with
# "python3 "array_dml_demo.py"

dsn   = input("Your ODBC DSN? ")
user  = input("Your Connect User? ")
pwd   = getpass.getpass("Your Connect Password? ")

conn = pyodbc.connect('DSN=' + dsn + ';UID=' + user + ';PWD=' + pwd + ';Trace=none;' )

def truncate_data():
  truncate_curs = conn.cursor()
  sql_truncate = "DELETE FROM ZWRITE.WriteView"
  truncate_curs.execute(sql_truncate)
  row_count = truncate_curs.rowcount
  print('Number of truncated rows: ' + str(row_count) )
  truncate_curs.close()

truncate_data()

# The following test code runs on a writable view entity exposed as 
#   ZWRITE.WriteView 
# with columns
#   key itemnr : abap.int4 not null;
#   key idate  : abap.datn not null;
#   amount     : abap.decfloat34;

# array data for insert
array_data = [
    (1, datetime.date(2023, 12, 24), 17 ),
    (2, datetime.date(2023, 12, 25), 4711 ),
    (3, datetime.date(2023, 12, 26), 1995 )
]

insert_curs = conn.cursor()
insert_curs.fast_executemany = True
sql_insert_with_values_clause = "INSERT INTO ZWRITE.WriteView VALUES (?, ?, ?)"
insert_curs.executemany(sql_insert_with_values_clause, array_data)
print('Insert Array Size: ' + str(len(array_data)) )
# pyodbc always returns row_count=-1 for executemany() ?!
# https://github.com/mkleehammer/pyodbc/issues/481
# row_count = insert_curs.rowcount
# print('Number of inserted rows: ' + str(row_count) )

sql_insert_select = "INSERT INTO ZWRITE.WriteView SELECT itemnr+3, DATN_ADD_DAYS(idate , 3), amount FROM ZWRITE.WriteView"
insert_curs.execute(sql_insert_select)
row_count = insert_curs.rowcount
print('Number of inserted rows: ' + str(row_count) )
insert_curs.close()

query_cursor = conn.cursor()
sql_query = "SELECT * FROM ZWRITE.WriteView"
query_cursor.execute(sql_query)
for row in query_cursor.fetchall():
    print (row)
query_cursor.close()

delete_curs = conn.cursor()
delete_curs.fast_executemany = True
sql_delete = "DELETE FROM ZWRITE.WriteView WHERE itemnr = ? AND idate = ? AND amount = ?"
delete_curs.executemany(sql_delete, array_data)
print('Delete Array Size: ' + str(len(array_data)) )

truncate_data()

# clean up
conn.close()

The output of the program could look as follows:

> python3 array_dml_demo.py

Your ODBC DSN? MYDSN
Your Connect User? MYUSER
Your Connect Password?

Number of truncated rows: 0

Insert Array Size: 3
Number of inserted rows: 3

(1, datetime.date(2023, 12, 24), Decimal('17'))
(2, datetime.date(2023, 12, 25), Decimal('4711'))
(3, datetime.date(2023, 12, 26), Decimal('1995'))
(4, datetime.date(2023, 12, 27), Decimal('17'))
(5, datetime.date(2023, 12, 28), Decimal('4711'))
(6, datetime.date(2023, 12, 29), Decimal('1995'))

Delete Array Size: 3

Number of truncated rows: 3

Conclusion

The SQL service now allows to expose writable view entities and the blog has shown some examples of the INSERT and DELETE statements that are now supported using the ABAP SQL service.

Please provide feedback if this information has been helpful for you. I am very curious about specific use cases and about the ODBC plugins/programs you have used to implement them.

Other Blogs Related to the ABAP SQL Service or the ODBC Driver for ABAP

Consuming CDS View Entities Using ODBC-Based Client Tools | SAP Blogs
Using the ODBC driver for ABAP on Linux | SAP Blogs
Access Control for ABAP‚Äôs SQL Service (1/3) ‚Äì Set the Scene | SAP Blogs
SQL Queries on CDS objects Exposed as SQL Service | SAP Blogs
Access CDS Objects Exposed as SQL Services Using Microsoft SQL Server | SAP Blogs
Data Science with SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì connect with Jupiter notebooks | SAP Blogs
HANA SDA. Accessing ABAP CDS View entities in HANA cloud  - SAP Blogs
Build an Azure Data Factory Pipeline with the ODBC driver for ABAP - SAP Blogs
Expose and Use ABAP-Managed Database Procedures (A... - SAP Community
Rust and ABAP ODBC - SAP Community

Links to SAP documentation

Data Integration (in the ABAP Integration and Connectivity Guide)

entry.title: Consignment Stock Update is not updated based on Ship to Customer in MSKU
entry.content:
We are using the SAP consignment stock process where the consignment stock is placed at a customer location. The stocks are required to be tracked based on where the stocks have been placed. However, the MSKU table does not record the consignment stock at the Ship to customer level and is recording the stock at the sold to level due to which there is a loss of information and visibility of the stock at a customer location. 

Please advise.

Regards

Rohit Zalani

entry.title: Push notifications using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Hello! 

I want to send notifications to user's mobiles. Is there any ability to do it using SAP Build Apps. I saw a lot of different documentations how to do it for SAP Fiory, etc. But in my case I created an app using SAP Build Apps - Frontend (No-Code) and tried to use action from marketplace "Request Notification Permissions". Then I was testing my app on my IPhone using SAP Build Apps Preview App and I always get an undefined error. So I can't allow to send notifications, then I can't retrieve Device ID Token and can't push notifications using FCM. 
Yeah, that was my idea to use FCM API and push notifications with a HTTP Request.
Then I tried to connect SAP Mobile Services, but again there are no good instructions or tutorials for no-code SAP Build Apps. I just can't understand how I can implement it using SAP Mobile Services.

I am asking for help in my case. May be there is a good structured tutorial for that...

Best regards,
Vladyslav

 

SAP Build Apps
